Home / Models / 3-Series / BMW to focus on being electric and autonomousâ€¦ BMW to focus on being electric and autonomous leader 3-Series | May 22nd, 2017 by Nico DeMattia 1 Tweet This current automotive landscape is a tricky one for automakers. Weâ€™re on the verge of a massive technology shift from the internal combustion engine, which â€¦ This current automotive landscape is a tricky one for automakers. Weâ€™re on the verge of a massive technology shift from the internal combustion engine, which every automaker has been using for over 100 years, to electric motors. While the change will be relatively drastic, and has been ongoing for some time, car companies are now starting to significantly increase their efforts in electric mobility and autonomous driving. According to BMW, the Bavarian brand plans on being the world leader in electric and autonomous tech, a goal it wants more than being the sales leader. BMW recently had its sales crown stripped from it by Mercedes-Benz. However, BMW CEO Harald Kruger claims that sales figures arenâ€™t as important to BMW as leading the industry in technology. Its success will come from being the best and most technologically-advanced brand on the market, rather than what the numbers on a sales sheet say. Kruger acknowledges, though, that BMW will need some help in this endeavor and cannot do it on itâ€™s own.Â â€œWe are not the best in making radars and vision controls, so we work with Mobileye,â€ he said. â€œWe do not make chips, so we cooperate with Intel. We have just taken on board Delphi to cooperate on software and system knowledge.â€ So with all of these brandsâ€™ expertise, itâ€™s certainly possible that BMW could lead the industry in advanced mobility tech quite soon. But donâ€™t just think that BMW is going to be transforming from a luxury car company into a boring tech company. â€œWe are in the premium business. We sell design and emotion, not just a way of getting from point A to B,â€ said Kruger. He also went on to say that there will never be a BMW that doesnâ€™t allow the driver to take over. Many enthusiasts are afraid that when autonomous cars come, BMWs will become little transportation pods, rather than the Ultimate Driving Machine they remember.Â â€œYou will never see a robo-taxi from BMW,â€ Kruger said, stating that BMWs will always have the option for the driver to drive.Â Although, that isnâ€™t slowing BMWâ€™s efforts into the world of autonomy. BMW is planning on the iNext 2021, a Level 4 autonomy-capable car that will begin production in, you guessed it, 2021. But it isnâ€™t just electric and autonomous vehicles that Bavarian brand is investing in. The brand wants to continue to invest into diesel technology, as it claims the new European emissions restrictions canâ€™t be met without diesels.Â  â€œYou need to invest in clean diesels, and Euro 6 engines are clean diesels,â€ said Kruger. We know that the automotive landscape is changing and we know that BMW will have to change with it. Adapt or die, right? But itâ€™s nice to know that the Bavarians wonâ€™t abandon their principles in the name of autonomy or electrification. BMWs will always drive like BMWs, even when electrons finally take over. Music News Entertainment Politics Features Share < br />this article: Chris Christie: â€˜I wouldnâ€™t let General Flynn into the White Houseâ€™ In News by Maggie Serota / May 22, 2017 Share < br />this article: Follow @maggieserota On Monday, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie went to bat for former FBI Director Jim Comey and tossed his fellow Trump transition team member Gen. Michael Flynn under the bus. Some of the noteworthy soundbites include Christie refuting Trumpâ€™s claim that the ousted FBI directorÂ is a â€œreal nut job.â€ â€œI would disagree with the characterization of Jim as a â€˜nut job,â€™â€ Christie, a former U.S. Attorney told reporters at a press conference held in the state capitol. â€œIâ€™ve known Jim for a long time. I donâ€™t always agree with him, as Iâ€™ve told you guys before, but, no, that wouldnâ€™t be the way I would characterize Jim.â€ Christie also took the opportunity to voice a public â€œtold ya soâ€ at the president when he discussed his reservations about appointing Gen. Michael Flynn as national security adviser. It turns out that President Obama wasnâ€™t the only person to warn Trump not to appoint the unhinged Islamaphobe with shady ties to Russia to a cabinet position, especially one that traffics in highly sensitive information. â€œI will just say this to you: If I was president of the United States, I wouldnâ€™t let General Flynn in the White House,â€ Christie, a failed 2016 GOP presidential candidate, said, â€œlet alone give him a job.â€ Christieâ€™s comments come in the wake of the report that Flynn will invoke 5th Amendment protection in declining to testify in front of the Senate Intel committee in the Russia probe. Christie makes it clear that there is no love lost between himself and Flynn. â€œI think itâ€™s safe to say that General Flynn and I didnâ€™t see eye to eye,â€ Christie said. â€œI didnâ€™t think he was someone who would bring benefit to the president or to the administration. And I made that very clear to candidate Trump and I made it very clear to President-elect Trump. That was my opinion, my view. Do I feel vindicated? I donâ€™t have any need to feel vindicated one way or the other.â€ Sorry, dude, you do not get to look like a hero at any point in this mess. Search for: About DCK Subscribe Events Training Main menu Skip to primary content Skip to secondary content Design Machine Learning Hyper-convergence Supercomputers Edge Computing Power and Cooling Hardware Storage Networks Open Source Manage Security DevOps DCIM Uptime Business Deals Investing Startups Regulation Colocation Cloud Energy How toâ€¦ Data Center World More Companies DCIM InfoCenter Humor Industry Perspectives Regions The Data Center Podcast The Apple Data Center FAQ The Facebook Data Center FAQ Google Data Center FAQ Data Center Knowledge Top Trending Articles Oracle Closes Big Cloud Deal With AT&T, Inks Equinix Partnership Massive, Six-Story Data Center in a Norwegian Mine Comes Online The Fat New Pipes that Link Facebook Data Centers Furious Land War Erupts Outside CME Data Center Cyxtera Puts a Fresh Spin on CenturyLinkâ€™s Former Data Center Empire Previous Article It Doesn't Take a Supercomputer to Justify Liquid Cooling Industry Perspectives Dell Technologies: Apple, or Just Bananas?Â  byÂ Industry Perspectives Â onÂ May 22, 2017 Add Your Comments Tweet Michael Beesley Skyport Systems Michael Beelsey is CTO of Skyport Systems. Today, Dell Technologies is one of the biggest hardware and software technology companies in the world with estimated annual revenues in the $60Â billion range, putting it neck and neck with Huawei for the title of worldâ€™s biggest private tech company. This has truly been an amazing journey for a company founded in 1984 on a $1,000 investment to sell IBM PC clones out of a dormitory room. Despite more than two decades of incredible success built around cost-effective manufacturing, rapid product introduction, industry best supply chain management and a direct to consumer business model, recently the company had struggled to maintain relevance and to avoid commoditization of its hardware- centric business model. In 2013, Michael Dell started taking a set of actions that amount to one of the biggest gambles ever taken in the world of technology; letâ€™s look at what he did, why, and how it might play out going forward. 2013: Dell is taken private through a private equity funded leveraged buyout; at $24Â billion it goes down in history as the largest technology buyout ever. 2016: Dell completes the $67Â billion acquisition of EMC Corp, the largest technology merger in history bringing EMC, VMware, RSA, Pivotal, SecureWorks and Virtustream all under the Dell Technologiesâ€™ umbrella. So why on earth did Michael Dell and team take on an eye-watering, terrifying mountain of debt to transform and enlarge his company, when others have the reverse strategy? The answer I believe has all to do with the rapid change being experienced in the enterprise data center, which has historically been a major profit center for infrastructure equipment and software vendors. Several things are changing: Public Cloud (IaaS and SaaS) Growth Public cloud (and the SaaS services hosted therein) continues to grow at a rapid rate and is literally eating the enterprise data center, which some areÂ predicting is doomed. Virtualization and â€˜Software Definedâ€™ Technology has evolved rapidly to the point that complex, critical functionality traditionally embedded in specialized storage, networking and security products is now offered as virtualized software running in and on the hypervisor of a server. Commoditization of Hardware Hardware system innovation has been at a standstill for years with every vendor having access to the same reference designs from Intel, Broadcom and others. As such, margins for systems have collapsed to commodity levels. Dellâ€™s Success Case: â€˜Appleâ€™ The success case for Dell is that it manages to stabilize the shift to cloud such that the worldâ€™s compute and storage remains evenly split between the public cloud and on-premise within enterprise. They establish a walled garden, integrated stack, including networking, storage, compute, virtualization and security, within enterprise, capturing 99Â percent global profit share from a much lower market share (as Apple has done in smartphones). It is worth noting that despite years of competition from Microsoftâ€™s System Center and from OpenStack (R.I.P â€“ enough said), VMware still commands 90-plus percent profit share in virtualization and orchestration. In this scenario, all competitors exit the data center market and Dell enjoys a monopoly in perpetuity within the enterprise becoming the worldâ€™s most valuable company. Dellâ€™s Failure Case: â€˜Just Bananasâ€™ The failure case involves endless migration to the public cloud to the point that the enterpriseÂ data center ceases to exist. Without the enterprise market, the global profit pool for vendors shrinks by an order of magnitude even though global compute and storage continue to increase. This is due to the scale effects and buying power of the small number of public cloud providers, combined with their penchant and abilities to engineer their own solutions if and when a commercial option becomes too expensive. In short, shops like AWS, Azure and GCE are the worst types of customer for an infrastructure or software vendor. The resulting business for Dell is at such thin margins that they cannot fund any research and developmentÂ and cannot create enough cash from operations to pay the interest on their debt. They go bankrupt. It will be fascinating to see how this all plays out over the next several years; it is very hard to predict the outcome, but one thing is for sure: The recent Dell moves will either go down in history as the bravest, wisest, most profitable move ever taken in tech, or they will go down as the most foolish, reckless, irresponsible, cash burning, company-destroying moves ever. Only time will tell. Opinions expressed in the article above do not necessarily reflect the opinions of Data Center Knowledge and Penton. Industry Perspectives is a content channel at Data Center Knowledge highlighting thought leadership in the data center arena. See our guidelines and submission process for information on participating. View previously published Industry Perspectives in our Knowledge Library. Flynn previously sought immunity inÂ exchange forÂ testifying, a point that led critics toÂ wonder what Flynn had toÂ hide. Clientron Displays POS Terminals with NFC Multi-Payment Solution at NRA Show 2017 Clientron displays POS terminals with NFC multi-payment solution at NRA Show 2017 (Graphic: Business Wire) Download Full Size Small Preview Thumbnail ???pagination.previous??? ???pagination.next??? Clientron displays POS terminals with NFC multi-payment solution at NRA Show 2017 (Graphic: Business Wire) Full Size Small Preview Thumbnail Small Preview Thumbnail May 22, 2017 12:30 PM Eastern Daylight Time TAIPEI, Taiwan--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Clientron Corp., a world leading provider of POS systems, announced the display of its full range of POS product innovations to comply with multi-payment solutions and various POS peripherals at NRA Show 2017 (National Restaurant Association), the largest annual gathering of the restaurant, foodservice and hospitality industries. This trade show is taking place from May 20 to 23 in Chicago. For the theme of our showcase, Clientron displays the latest generation of its POS product portfolio. For all-in-one POS terminals, Clientron offers the all new multi-functional Bello 620/650/650w featuring high integration with 12â€ / 15â€ / 15.6â€ touch screen options, supporting dual customer displays as well as a built-in NFC smart card reader with EMV L1/ L2 for user experience enhancement. Bello just won the â€œTaiwan Excellence Award 2017â€ this year for its innovation and the best quality design, which makes it stand out from numerous products as the best choice for POS applications. In addition, Clientron showcases its butterfly light-weight POS terminal Wing series with a flexible dual-hinge stand, and the mainstream Ares650 series with an advanced ultra-slim system design. Both Wing350w and Ares650 won the â€œTaiwan Excellence Award 2016â€. Moreover, we exhibit the most economic POS terminal PT3200, which is equipped with an Intel power efficient quad-core processor to offer a fanless system with a long life span that is matched with an affordable price. Also at this event, a variety of extended POS peripherals are exhibited. â€œSeizing the booming opportunity for multi-payment solutions, Clientron delivers flexible integrated POS systems and customer-centric design services that support retailers to meet the ever-changing demands of their customers and improve overall business operation,â€ said Kelly Wu, President & CEO of Clientron Corp. To know more about Clientronâ€™s design, manufacturing capabilities and services, please visit Clientron at booth #5564, North Hall, McCormick Place in Chicago. Clientron website: www.clientron.com About Clientron Clientron was founded in 1983. The company is dedicated in providing global intelligent solutions to our clients. With design, manufacturing and service abilities, Clientron offers high-quality and high-performance computing platforms including Thin Client, POS and Intelligent Systems. We commit to continuously provide better IoT client solutions and services for our partners and customers to build an intelligent e-World. Visit us at www.clientron.com. Contacts Clientron Corp. Welcome, then, the HP Spectre X2, the latest in the laptop companyâ€™s range of touchscreen 2-in-1s. With the body of a tablet â€“ and a 12.3-inch, 3,000 x 2,000 resolution one at that â€“ and the flexibility of a magnetically-attached keyboard, HP is hoping youâ€™ll forget all about your Surface Pro dreams. At first glance, it might just do that. The Spectre X2 certainly looks the part, with a CNC-machined aluminum chassis finished in dark ash silver; the pop-out kickstand is made of stainless steel, but given a striking copper finish that really pops. Itâ€™ll stand the tablet up at any angle between flat and 165-degrees. The keyboard, meanwhile, is full-sized, has backlit keys, and a glass trackpad. As with previous Spectre detachables, it uses magnets to cling in place. Atop the touchscreen thereâ€™s a 5-megapixel wide-angle camera and an infrared camera, which can be used for Windows Hello, and dual digital microphones. A 13-megapixel camera is on the back, and HP throws a digital stylus in the box. The speakers are tuned by Bang & Olufsen. Itâ€™s inside where things get really interesting, mind. HP has thrown in up to Intelâ€™s 7th-generation Core i7-7560U processor, paired with up to 8GB of LPDDR3 memory. Thereâ€™s a 360GB PCIe SSD for storage, and Intel Iris Plus Graphics 650. The 41.58 Wh li-ion battery, HP claims, should last for up to 8 hours of mixed use, or 7 hours and 15 minutes of solid video playback. More usefully, thanks to HP Fast Charge, itâ€™ll go from flat to 50-percent in half an hour. Itâ€™s worth noting that you canâ€™t actually be using it during that time if you want to see such speed, and beyond the half-battery point itâ€™ll go back to the regular charging rate. Connectivity includes 802.11ac and Bluetooth 4.2. There are two USB 3.1 Type-C ports for up to 5Gb/s data, DisplayPort 1.2, charging the Spectre X2, and using HPâ€™s Sleep and Charge to power up connected peripherals even when the 2-in-1 itself is turned off. HP includes a USB-C to USB Type-A adapter for older device you might have; itâ€™s a small touch, but itâ€™s something Apple neglects to do with the latest MacBook Pro. Otherwise, thereâ€™s a headphone/microphone combo port and a microSD slot. The whole thing weighs in at 2.49 pounds. In short, if you canâ€™t wait for Microsoft to get around to upgrading the Surface Pro 4, your 2-in-1 dreams arenâ€™t dashed. The HP Spectre x2 will go up for sale in June, priced from $999.99. Photo: Wikimedia Commons. Israelâ€™s economy minister wants to boost the Jewish stateâ€™s exports to the US over fivefold by the end of this decade. In a statement issued as President Donald Trump began his official visit to Israel, Eli Cohen said that â€œone of our main goals is to increase Israeli exports to the US to more than $100 billion by 2020.â€ In 2016, trade of goods between the US and Israel reached $27 billion â€” $17.6 billion of which consisted of Israeli exports to America.Â Trade of goods constitutes some 50 percent of economic activity between the two countries. Trading in services constitutes 19 percent, and investments make up the additional 31 percent, according to statistics from Israelâ€™s Ministry of Economy and Industry. Growing consumer electronics market and implementation of IoT in market is driving photomask market in the coming year. Asia Pacific including Taiwan, Korea, and Japan together holds the largest share of photomask market in last five years and the trend is expected to remain same for the duration of the forecast. The photomask market is a concentrated market with less than 20 leading players only, comprising some of the major chipmakers such as Intel, IBM, NEC, TSMC, Global foundries, UMC, Samsung, and Micron Technology. These companies have their own large mask-making facilities or joint ventures with the photomask companies.  Microsoft wants to store data in DNA Antonio Regalado, MIT Technology Review May 22, 2017, 12:19 PM 1,206 facebook linkedin twitter email print Dragan Radovanovic/Business Insider Based on early research involving the storage of movies and documents in DNA, Microsoft is developing an apparatus that uses biology to replace tape drives, researchers at the company say. Computer architects at Microsoft Research say the company has formalized a goal of having an operational storage system based on DNA working inside a data center toward the end of this decade. The aim is a â€œproto-commercial system in three years storing some amount of data on DNA in one of our data centers, for at least a boutique application,â€ says Doug Carmean, a partner architect at Microsoft Research. He describes the eventual device as the size of a large, 1970s-era Xerox copier. Internally, Microsoft harbors the even more ambitious goal of replacing tape drives, a common format used for archiving information. â€œWe hope to get it branded as â€˜Your Storage with DNA,â€™â€ says Carmean. The plans signal how seriously some tech companies are taking the seemingly strange idea of saving videos, photos, or valuable documents in the same molecule our genes are made of. The reason, says Victor Zhirnov, chief scientist of the Semiconductor Research Corporation, is that efforts to shrink computer memory are hitting physical limits, but DNA can store data at incredible densities. Formatted in DNA, every movie ever made would fit inside a volume smaller than a sugar cube.Â  â€œDNA is the densest known storage medium in the universe, just based on the laws of physics. That is the reason why people are looking into this,â€ says Zhirnov. â€œAnd the problem we are solving is the exponential growth of stored information.â€Â  Last July, Microsoft publicly announced it had stored 200 megabytes of data in DNA strands, including a music video, setting a record. The work, described in a paper published in MarchÂ on the pre-print server Biorxiv, has been led by Carmean and Karin Strauss, both of Microsoft Research, and the University of Washington laboratory of computer scientist Luis Ceze. Major obstacles to a practical storage system remain. Converting digital bits into DNA code (made up of chains of nucleotides labeled A, G, C, and T) remains laborious and expensive because of the chemical process used to manufacture DNA strands. In its demonstration project, Microsoft used 13,448,372 unique pieces of DNA. Experts say buying that much material on the open market would cost $800,000. â€œThe main issue with DNA storage is the cost,â€ says Yaniv Erlich, a professor at Columbia University who earlier this year reported a novel approach to DNA data storage. â€œSo the main question is whether Microsoft solved this problem.â€ The main issue with DNA storage is the cost,Â so the main question is whether Microsoft solved this problem. Based on their publication, Erlich says, â€œI did not see any progress towards this goal, but maybe they have something in their pipeline.â€ According to Microsoft, the cost of DNA storage needs to fall by a factor of 10,000 before it becomes widely adopted. While many experts say thatâ€™s unlikely, Microsoft believes such advances could occur if the computer industry demands them. Automating the process of writing digital data into DNA will also be critical. Based on the several weeks it took to carry out their experiment, Carmean estimates that the rate of moving data into DNA was only 400 bytes per second. Microsoft says that needs to increase to 100 megabytes per second. Reading the data out is easier. That was done using a high-speed sequencing machine, including to recall specific parts of the files, analogous to random-access memory on a computer. Even a two-fold improvement in DNA reading would make that aspect of the system efficient enough for commercial use, Microsoft thinks. Â Â  Because writing and retrieving data into DNA is slow, any early use of the technology will be restricted to special situations. That could include data that needs to be archived for legal or regulatory reasons,Â such as police body-cam video or medical records. Microsoft currently works with Twist Bioscience, a DNA manufacturer located in San Francisco. Twist is one of a number of newly formed companies trying to improve DNA production, a list that now includes startups DNAScript, Nuclera Nucleics, Evonetix, Molecular Assemblies, Catalog DNA, Helixworks, and a spin-off of Oxford Nanopore called Genome Foundry. One exciting possibility being pursued by some of the startups is to replace the 40-year-old chemical process used to make DNA with one that employs enzymes, as our own bodies do. Jean Bolot, scientific director of Technicolor Research, in Los Altos, says it is funding such work at Harvard University, in the laboratory of George Church, the genomics expert. â€œI am confident we will have results to talk about thisÂ year,â€ says Bolot, who adds that his company has been in discussionsÂ with movie studios about how they might employ DNA storage. He says half of all films made before 1951 are already lost because they were stored on celluloid. Now new formats, like high-definition video and virtual reality, are stretching studiosâ€™ ability to preserve their work, he says. Zhirnov says computer chip makers are taking DNA seriously because there are physical limits to how much data can be stored in conventional media, like tapes or hard drives. His organization, which is funded by Microsoft, Intel, and others to perform applied research, began taking a closer look at DNA starting in 2013. He says semiconductor experts who believed DNA was too â€œsoftâ€ were surprised to learn that it lasts a hundred to a thousand times longer than a silicon device. The molecule is so stable that it is frequently recovered from mammoth bones and ancient human remains. But its most important feature is density. DNA can hold 1,000,000,000,000,000,000 (aka a quintillion) bytes of information in a cubic millimeter. â€œDensity is driving everything,â€ says Zhirnov. A spokesperson for Microsoft Research said the company could not confirm â€œspecifics on a product planâ€ at this time. Inside the company, the DNA storage idea is apparently gaining adherents but is not yet universally accepted. â€œOur internal people believe us, but not the tape storage people,â€ says Carmean, formerly a top chip designer at Intel. Â  In addition to being dense and durable, DNA has a furtherÂ advantage thatâ€™s not often mentionedâ€”its extreme relevance to the human species. Think of those old floppy disks you canâ€™t read anymore or clay tablets with indecipherable hieroglyphs. Unlike such media, DNA probably wonâ€™t ever go out of style. â€œWeâ€™ll always be reading DNA as long as we are human,â€ says Carmean. Get the latest Microsoft stock price here. Read the original article on MIT Technology Review. Copyright 2017. Follow MIT Technology Review on Twitter.
